Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis of Glycogen in Bacteria and Starch in Plants: Structure-Function Relationship of the ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will study the evolution and structure of ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylases, which are the enzymes that control the production of starch in plants and glycogen in bacteria. This is an interesting case study because this enzyme evolved to acquire different catalytic and regulatory roles according to the necessities of the organism. Despite the divergence in catalysis and regulation between plant and bacterial forms, it seems that there is a common mechanism to trigger the regulation. Specifically, this project will try to identify how catalytic function has diverged along the evolutionary tree of ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylases and identify the responsible regions for the common regulatory trigger for activation. Different techniques will be used, including molecular cloning, mutagenesis, computational and biochemical studies. The characterization of conserved and divergent functional elements of this enzyme will explain how new roles can evolve in an enzyme family such as the one from ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylases.

Broader impacts
A better understanding of the functional evolution of the ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase could lead to a rational manipulation of their properties. Consequently, transgenic plants with modified ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylases may improve agriculturally important crops or algae for biofuel production. Several aspects of the research will have an educational impact in the society. 1) Undergraduate students will be trained to perform research and learn the ethic of science, which will be an irreplaceable experience for a future professional, or a deciding factor to become a scientist. 2) Two graduate students will be trained, who will possibly become either a future scientist or teacher. Considering that there are several underrepresented minorities in science and women studying in the Department of Chemistry at Loyola University Chicago, it is likely that this project will benefit an underrepresented fragment of the population. 3) International workshops will be organized in Santa Fe (Argentina) and Chicago (USA) to enhance the research education of American graduate and/or senior undergraduate students. 4) Faculty and staff of Loyola's Center for Science and Math Education will collaborate to develop model lessons for high school teachers based on the scope of this proposed research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merits

Our project studied the evolution and structure of ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylases, which are the enzymes that control ("regulate") the production of starch in plants and glycogen in bacteria (they store energy in times of abundance). This is an important case study because they evolved to acquire regulatory roles according to the necessities of the organism (more nutrients available, more storage of starch/glycogen).

There were two aspects to investigate about the evolution of the regulation of starch/glycogen synthesis. First, different metabolites trigger the regulation in diverse species, so we explored how this metabolite recognition evolved. Second, we researched how the regulatory signal was transmitted by the ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase enzyme once the metabolites are bound and recognized. In addition, we explored whether this signal has evolved too.

In unicellular algae, we found that after gene duplication, an ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase gene lost specificity for the metabolite that regulates it compared to how it is done in bacteria. This widespread evolutionary flexibility (promiscuity) seems to be ancestral and intrinsic to the enzyme family. This constitutes an effective mechanism to accommodate the regulation of starch/glycogen to different metabolic needs.

Opposite results were observed with the “regulatory signal” in the ADP-Glc PPase enzyme family. We found that it has been conserved throughout evolution. Both in plants and bacteria, there are specific residues that are critical "to communicate" the regulation. This communication pathway was detected by computational studies and confirmed by mutations. Once the pathway was detected, we confirmed it is present in very diverse species. Our conclusion is that this enzyme maintains an "evolutionary flexible" site to bind the regulators, but once they bind, the triggered signal is identical and follow the same paths in the enzyme. It was not necessary to evolve different signals, but only what metabolites would trigger them.

The regulation of this enzyme was acquired when an ancestral gene was linked (fused) to another fragment (domain). This extra fragment created a crevice where the activators bind. To prove this hypothesis, we reproduced in the laboratory the fusion events to show that an enzyme that was not originally regulated could acquire a proto-regulation by the addition of the regulatory fragment.

Another striking finding in this project was that the enzyme from Escherichia coli is synergistically activated by two different activators (pyruvate and fructose 1,6-bisphosphate). This actually explained why many enzymes evolved to have different degrees of activation by different more than one activator. There is actually more than one site. In fact, we characterized other enzymes with other regulatory profiles such as the ones from Streptococcus mutans and Nitrosomonas europaea

Broader impacts

The understanding of the functional evolution of the ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase will lead to a rational manipulation of their properties. Consequently, this project will pave the way in the future to modify ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylases that may improve agriculturally important crops or algae for biofuel production.

Several aspects of the research had already an educational impact. We have trained five undergraduate students a year to perform research. For them, the experience was critical for their professional future (some of them in the health profession and others in graduate school). Three graduate students have contributed to the project, and two of them already graduated. The knowledge and the training they acquired will have a great impact since they are pursuing careers in teaching. We established collaboration with scientists from Argentina, which was very helpful for our students. They had the ability to interact and learn from them when they visit every year our institution. This international exposure has been enlightening for both our undergraduate and graduate students. In addition, this project welcomed high school students during the summer and during the year with special workshops organized by the Department. One of the positive outcomes of this project is that we were able to transfer the knowledge we obtained in our research to the classroom. We designed and modelled two biochemistry laboratory courses for our senior majors based on our research. In this way, all of our majors will benefit from this NSF funded project by learning from it, and also contributing with some of the experiments they ran.
